citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee failed to trim the approximate 19 rabbits’ overgrown nails cited on the last inspection by the correction date
of 26-May-2023. He trimmed one of those rabbit’s nails but is waiting for the attending veterinarian to trim the rest of their
nails on 8-June-2023. He trimmed an additional rabbit’s nails during this inspection. Excessively long toenails can break
and cause injury as well as affect the animal’s gait when walking. Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent,
control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee must trim all the rabbits’ nails and create an appropriate
plan to ensure the nails are kept at a proper length.
The licensee failed to have the black and white, adult, male rabbit with nasal discharge and sneezing evaluated by a
licensed veterinarian by the correction date of 26-March-2023. The inspector asked what the veterinarian had prescribed
for this rabbit, the licensee showed a container of TC Vet with directions stating "use as directed". No other
documentation of the rabbit being evaluated so the inspector called the attending veterinarian, whom stated he had not
seen the rabbit. The licensee only spoke to the attending veterinarian and the licensee suggested an antibiotic treatment
prescribed by another licensed veterinarian in July 2022. The attending veterinarian agreed to this treatment and the
rabbit did not have nasal discharge when looked at by the inspector on 31-May-2023 and seemed bright, alert, and
responsive. The attending veterinarian is scheduled to evaluate this rabbit during the 8-June-2023 facility visit. Failure to
have the rabbit evaluated in person by a licensed veterinarian does not ensure the rabbit is receiving appropriate
veterinary care. Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries.
The licensee must have the above-mentioned rabbit evaluated by a licensed veterinarian.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee failed to trim the approximate 19 rabbits’ overgrown nails cited on the last inspection by the correction date 
of 26-May-2023. He trimmed one of those rabbit’s nails but is waiting for the attending veterinarian to trim the rest of their 
nails on 8-June-2023. He trimmed an additional rabbit’s nails during this inspection. Excessively long toenails can break 
and cause injury as well as affect the animal’s gait when walking. Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, 
control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee must trim all the rabbits’ nails and create an appropriate 
plan to ensure the nails are kept at a proper length. 
 
The licensee failed to have the black and white, adult, male rabbit with nasal discharge and sneezing evaluated by a 
licensed veterinarian by the correction date of 26-March-2023. The inspector asked what the veterinarian had prescribed 
for this rabbit, the licensee showed a container of TC Vet with directions stating "use as directed". No other 
documentation of the rabbit being evaluated so the inspector called the attending veterinarian, whom stated he had not 
seen the rabbit. The licensee only spoke to the attending veterinarian and the licensee suggested an antibiotic treatment 
prescribed by another licensed veterinarian in July 2022. The attending veterinarian agreed to this treatment and the 
rabbit did not have nasal discharge when looked at by the inspector on 31-May-2023 and seemed bright, alert, and 
responsive. The attending veterinarian is scheduled to evaluate this rabbit during the 8-June-2023 facility visit. Failure to

have the rabbit evaluated in person by a licensed veterinarian does not ensure the rabbit is receiving appropriate 
veterinary care. Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries. 
The licensee must have the above-mentioned rabbit evaluated by a licensed veterinarian. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
